column9: Lifetime: The number of people who had your Page's post enter their screen. Posts include statuses, photos, links, videos and more. (Unique Users)
column10: Lifetime: The number of people who had your Page's post enter their screen through unpaid distribution. (Unique Users)
column11: Lifetime: The number of people who had your Page's post enter their screen through paid distribution such as an ad. (Unique Users)
column12: Lifetime: The number of times your Page's post entered a person's screen. Posts include statuses, photos, links, videos and more. (Total Count)
column13: Lifetime: The number of times your Page's posts entered a person's screen through unpaid distribution. (Total Count)
column14: Lifetime: The number of times your Page's post entered a person's screen through paid distribution such as an ad. (Total Count)
column15: Lifetime: The number of unique people who engaged in certain ways with your Page post, for example by commenting on, liking, sharing, or clicking upon particular elements of the post. (Unique Users)
column16: Lifetime: The number of people who matched the audience targeting that clicked anywhere in your post on News Feed. (Unique Users)
column17: Lifetime: The number of clicks anywhere in your post on News Feed from the user that matched the audience targeting on it. (Total Count)
column18: Lifetime: The number of people who have given negative feedback to your post. (Unique Users)
column19: Lifetime: The number of times people have given negative feedback to your post. (Total Count)
column20: Lifetime: The number of impressions of your Page post to people who have liked your Page. (Total Count)
column21: Lifetime: The number of people who saw your Page post because they've liked your Page (Unique Users)
column22: Lifetime: The number of paid impressions of your Page post to people who have liked your Page. (Total Count)
column23: Lifetime: The number of people who like your Page and who saw your Page post in an ad or sponsored story. (Unique Users)
column24: Lifetime: The number of people who have liked your Page and clicked anywhere in your posts. (Unique Users)
column25: Lifetime: Number of times your video was viewed to 95% of its length without any paid promotion. (Unique Users)
column26: Lifetime: Number of times your video was viewed to 95% of its length without any paid promotion. (Total Count)
column27: Lifetime: Number of times your video was viewed to 95% of its length after paid promotion. (Unique Users)
column28: Lifetime: Number of times your video was viewed to 95% of its length after paid promotion. (Total Count)
column29: Lifetime: Number of times your video was viewed for more than 3 seconds without any paid promotion. (Unique Users)
column30: Lifetime: Number of times your video was viewed for more than 3 seconds without any paid promotion. (Total Count)
column31: Lifetime: Number of times your video was viewed more than 3 seconds after paid promotion. (Unique Users)
column32: Lifetime: Number of times your video was viewed more than 3 seconds after paid promotion. (Total Count)
column33: Lifetime: Average time video viewed (Total Count)
column34: Lifetime: Length of a video post (Total Count)
column35: Lifetime: The number of unique people who created a story about your Page post by interacting with it. (Unique Users)
column38: Lifetime: The number of stories created about your Page post, by action type. (Total Count)
column41: Lifetime: The number of people who matched the audience targeting on the post that clicked anywhere in the post on News Feed, by type. (Unique Users)
column44: Lifetime: The number of clicks anywhere in the post on News Feed from users that matched the audience targeting on the post, by type. (Total Count)
column47: Lifetime: The number of times people have given negative feedback to your post, by type. (Total Count)
column48: Lifetime: The number of people who have given negative feedback to your post, by type. (Unique Users)

column3:
Wow! Shout out to The Bravesome for repping Open TV series 3 times on this list of 6 Web Series By/Featuring Black and Brown Women and Femmes. 

Geeta's Guide To Moving On, Brown Girls, and You're So Talented are all up here! 

https://www.thebravesome.com/single-post/2017/06/28/6-Web-Series-ByFeaturing-Black-and-Brown-Women-and-Femmes

Triggers, a short by Kai M. Green, is now available on our site! 

Triggers is a short film that centers black women and girls’ trauma. A poetic journey through the weight of witness, the stories of Marissa Alexander and other instances of intimate partner violence that I witnessed as an adult and a child are central. I talk to my former little black girl self. This piece honors her struggle and the struggles of little black girls everywhere. What does it mean to hold the history of a little black girl in my trans-male body? Or better, how does it feel?

Triggers stars Kai M Green, Anna Martine Whitehead, Julian Kevon Glover, and Mlondi Zondi.

ambivert. by Fempow Tarot is now available on our site! 

ambivert. is a meditation in manic visuals and ethereal sounds. Transmuting energy from chronic pain, anxiety, and lethargy into thrusting sexual freedom, joy, anger, empathy for self and communities of color.
Starting in half an hour babes! Can't wait to kiki with y'all.

We are so excited to be a part of Jen Richards and Laura Zak's Vimeo picks for Pride Month! 

Brown Girls and Brujos are in great company alongside some other brilliant works like Suicide Kale and Honey and the Trombones by Tayarisha Poe. Check out the rest of the list!
Come say hi for our last event of the season! It's FREE.99 -- you know how we do. Bring bae and a snack. Can't wait to share season two with all of you!

We know y'all are crawling out of your #pride spiral. 

Come recharge with us tomorrow night for a potluck n chill at Reunion Chicago and get a preview of the entire first season of Two Queens in a Kitchen!
Miss our Ideas on Fire webinar Art and Community-Based Research with Aymar Jean Christian?  Catch the replay anytime
OTV - Open Television
OTV - Open Television
Welcome Ashley Ray and Jordy Marilyn! So excited to share what you've come up with!
No Coast Cinema does a deep dive into Afternoon Snatch with creators Ruby Western and Kayla Ginsburg! #AfternoonSnatch
OTV - Open Television

Catch us for one our last events of the season before our annual hiatus! 

Join OPEN TV - beta for the first public preview of the second season of Two Queens in a Kitchen (#2QIK), a turn-to-relevance cooking show featuring Chicago’s queens and queers discussing family, home, politics, culture, and art while making a healthy snack. Expect to feel right at home as we close out Pride&Power, Reunion Chicago’s monthlong celebration of queer-centered programming. Bring a snack, a bottle of your favorite booze, and your Summer boo and lets Kiki down with Chicago’s most fly queers and queens on the scene!

#BrownGirlsTV screens this week at the #Frameline41 film festival! The festival graciously reviewed it: 

"From expert exiting of dates with the skill of a thousand unapologetic, sex-positive, no-time-for-nonsense black feminists, to coming for your sorta-ex-bae’s date at a party, to deciding just when you’re going to fight for your own happiness, Brown Girls features layered and personal storylines. With moments of laugh-out-loud hilarity coupled with challenging conversations with chosen and blood family, the season ultimately strikes a steady note throughout episodes that are as varied as the main characters themselves."

Thank you to our latest backers taking us over $5K, including Open TV advisory committee member Christopher Audain, along with Allison Glenn, Miles Grier, Mark Thiel​, Patrick Hilsman, Michael Smith, Adrienne Shaw, Alexandrina Agloro, Andrew Griffin, & Kevin Gotkin!

Thank you for supporting our experimental TV show #SerialDreamer! 3arts.org/projects/serial-dreamer

WTTW - Chicago PBS explores what the Brown Girls/HBO deal means for Chicago and Hollywood's openness to diversity. Thanks Nicole Cardos!

On #Hollywood:
“The industry, historically, has been so afraid of identities that can’t be easily translated to a mainstream narrative,” Aymar Jean Christian said. “The lesson is to tell a good story with interesting characters who ring true to the people who are represented. It’s actually that simple.”

On #Chicago:
“I feel like Chicago has always been a place where you can semi-afford it still, still do your art outside of your day job in the way that LA and New York kind of doesn’t allow that,” Samantha Bailey said. “Chicago kind of sets that up and gives those characters a chance to figure things out in a way that if they lived in one of the cities we’re used to seeing on TV, it wouldn’t be as authentic.”
OTV - Open Television

We love when critics engage with our work: "‘Geeta’s Guide To Moving On’ wins because of it’s light, frothy screenplay." Thanks The Digital Hash!

Episodes can be viewed here: http://www.weareopen.tv/open-tv-originals//geetas-guide-to-moving-on

TV ASIA Channel covered the premiere of #GeetaGuide! Check out their story and interview with Puja Mohindra and Aymar Jean Christian at the Chicago Cultural Center explaining why Puja made this comedy about heartbreak for everyone and the Indian community specifically.

Here we go behbehs! #2QIK LIVE and the preview of season two to follow at 8:30

@Soho House Chicago

Support trans-led media and make a tax-deductible donation today! 
#americaintransition #webelong

India West interviewed Puja Mohindra about why she made #GeetasGuide!

“The story is universal, it’s just told through a cultural specific lens,” Mohindra told India-West about the show, which was also in the final consideration for the Sundance YouTube Lab. “It didn’t occur to me until I went through [a break-up] how difficult it is for our parents to understand…most of the parents of the first-generation kids did not have the opportunity to fall in love and they often did not have a break-up.”

Thank you India West for featuring Geeta's Guide To Moving On! 

“The story is universal, it’s just told through a cultural specific lens,” Puja Mohindra told India-West about the show, which was also in the final consideration for the Sundance YouTube Lab. “Literally every human on the planet goes through a loss; how universal loss is…it could be a partner, a parent, a pet, a job; nobody of any race, background or age is not prone to love at some point in life.”

Describing the series as a “comedy with a heart,” Mohindra noted that the more she shared this one girl’s journey to move on, the more she learnt about the strength of the human spirit."

#GeetasGuide

Post-screening talkback from The Petty Biennial Film Screening with Suné Woods, Derrick Woods Morrow, Rashayla Marie Brown, Ester Alegria and Kai Green, moderated by Aymar Jean Christian and Anna Martine Whitehead.
See y'all tonight !

Open TV (beta) founder Aymar Jean Christian and artists Fawz Mirza and Puja Mohindra spoke about diversifying new media at #SXSW17!

"What we need now are distributors who can aggregate audiences and not only direct funding to production but just make marketing a little easier for creators. It's great to have all these stories, but I think people need to see them for [diversity and representation] conversations to proliferate," Christian said. 

"The way that [people of color] move and create in the world is a way of creating empathy, conversation and connection," Mirza said.

Northwestern University News offers the research perspective on the Brown Girls x HBO deal. 

“We were essentially ‘Brown Girls’ first network, assisting in production and exhibition with funding and marketing,” Aymar Jean Christian said. “The point of Open TV is to slowly build an audience for intersectional and queer programming to see how that kind of distribution might develop, since networks like HBO don't consistently develop diverse programming.”

WE GOT THE GREEN LIGHT. 6 days after launching, #SerialDreamer is 101% funded through 3Arts!

We're confirmed to get the money but we have NOT crossed the finish line: we have a stretch goal of $10,000! https://3arts.org/projects/serial-dreamer

$5,000 gets us a great scene introducing the characters at their co-op meeting. If we can double that, we will have enough to produce a dream sequence for each character! These dreams show the inner life of these characters, almost like mini-music videos. The funds go toward licensing music and producing the sequences.

All photos from the 2nd Annual Open TV Friendraiser are now live! 

All photos by Jackie Elizabeth
2nd Annual Open TV Friendraiser

The "infinitely charming and hugely popular series" Brown Girls leads Vimeo's Pride Month programming! "There’s such a fabulous and diverse tapestry of LGBTQ+ creators and experiences to explore on Vimeo," writes staffer Anton De Ionno.

Thank youuu to all of our wonderful donors that have contributed so far and gotten us over 2/3rds of the way to our goal so quickly! 

We have 29 days to go, help make #SerialDreamer a reality and support queer, intersectional TV. 

Donate: https://3arts.org/projects/serial-dreamer/

Serial Dreamer is an ambitious experiment in queer TV development: a series of pilots about intersectional characters. In the full series, each episode focuses on one of the co-op residents and we follow them in their everyday lives and jump into their dreams. Inspired as I was by dreaming while running to music, I imagine these worlds as music videos embedded in a serial narrative, but that may vary based on each artist’s vision and resources. Each episode will ideally have the same cinematographer but different directors and creative teams. Characters may show up in other series, or not. The relations in the show will be as organic as relationships in the real world.

We're launching an ambitious new experiment: #SerialDreamer! Created by founder Aymar Jean Christian in collaboration with a diverse group of Chicago artists from the #OpenTVCommunity, Serial Dreamer follows residents of a Chicago co-op in their everyday lives and their dreams.

Dr. Christian writes: 

Chicago’s artists inspired me to dream. A few years ago when I was new to Chicago, I would run down Lakeshore Drive, listening to R&B and dreaming of televisual narratives. I was serially dreaming, casting as characters the artists who would eventually become my collaborators on Open TV (beta), a research project and web platform that I created to develop artistic, intersectional TV. With this campaign, I am asking you to support Serial Dreamer: Co-Op, a collaborative comedy pilot for a new series of stories about residents in a Chicago co-op as they dream about other worlds. The full series will follow a different character in each episode through their everyday life and their dreams. Each character and story line is created by a writer who has pitched or produced a project during Open TV's first two cycles or participated in the Open TV Writers Group during our residency at the Chicago Cultural Center. This project is an experiment in using queer TV development to mobilize our community and exponentially increase the number of artistic, intersectional TV stories coming out of Chicago. Serial Dreamer: Co-Op represents my dream for Open TV: ever-growing, ever-evolving, community-driven, and continually generating value from telling diverse stories.
